class.name: Vector2i
class.description: A 2-element structure that can be used to represent 2D grid coordinates or any other pair of integers. It uses integer coordinates and is therefore preferable to [Vector2] when exact precision is required. Note that the values are limited to 32 bits, and unlike [Vector2] this cannot be configured with an engine build option. Use [int] or [PackedInt64Array] if 64-bit values are needed. [b]Note:[/b] In a boolean context, a Vector2i will evaluate to [code]false[/code] if it's equal to [code]Vector2i(0, 0)[/code]. Otherwise, a Vector2i will always evaluate to [code]true[/code].

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a default-initialized [Vector2i] with all components set to [code]0[/code].

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a [Vector2i] as a copy of the given [Vector2i].

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a new [Vector2i] from the given [Vector2] by truncating components' fractional parts (rounding towards zero). For a different behavior consider passing the result of [method Vector2.ceil], [method Vector2.floor] or [method Vector2.round] to this constructor instead.

constructor.name: Vector2i
constructor.description: Constructs a new [Vector2i] from the given [param x] and [param y].

method.name: abs
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components in absolute values (i.e. positive).

method.name: aspect
method.description: Returns the aspect ratio of this vector, the ratio of [member x] to [member y].

method.name: clamp
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components clamped between the components of [param min] and [param max], by running [method @GlobalScope.clamp] on each component.

method.name: clampi
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components clamped between [param min] and [param max], by running [method @GlobalScope.clamp] on each component.

method.name: distance_squared_to
method.description: Returns the squared distance between this vector and [param to]. This method runs faster than [method distance_to], so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

method.name: distance_to
method.description: Returns the distance between this vector and [param to].

method.name: length
method.description: Returns the length (magnitude) of this vector.

method.name: length_squared
method.description: Returns the squared length (squared magnitude) of this vector. This method runs faster than [method length], so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

method.name: max
method.description: Returns the component-wise maximum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector2i(maxi(x, with.x), maxi(y, with.y))[/code].

method.name: max_axis_index
method.description: Returns the axis of the vector's highest value. See [code]AXIS_*[/code] constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [constant AXIS_X].

method.name: maxi
method.description: Returns the component-wise maximum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector2i(maxi(x, with), maxi(y, with))[/code].

method.name: min
method.description: Returns the component-wise minimum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector2i(mini(x, with.x), mini(y, with.y))[/code].

method.name: min_axis_index
method.description: Returns the axis of the vector's lowest value. See [code]AXIS_*[/code] constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [constant AXIS_Y].

method.name: mini
method.description: Returns the component-wise minimum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector2i(mini(x, with), mini(y, with))[/code].

method.name: sign
method.description: Returns a new vector with each component set to [code]1[/code] if it's positive, [code]-1[/code] if it's negative, and [code]0[/code] if it's zero. The result is identical to calling [method @GlobalScope.sign] on each component.

method.name: snapped
method.description: Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the closest multiple of the corresponding component in [param step].

method.name: snappedi
method.description: Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the closest multiple of [param step].

members.member: The vector's X component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][0][/code].
The vector's Y component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][1][/code].

constants.constant: Enumerated value for the X axis. Returned by [method max_axis_index] and [method min_axis_index].
Enumerated value for the Y axis. Returned by [method max_axis_index] and [method min_axis_index].
Zero vector, a vector with all components set to [code]0[/code].
One vector, a vector with all components set to [code]1[/code].
Min vector, a vector with all components equal to [code]INT32_MIN[/code]. Can be used as a negative integer equivalent of [constant Vector2.INF].
Max vector, a vector with all components equal to [code]INT32_MAX[/code]. Can be used as an integer equivalent of [constant Vector2.INF].
Left unit vector. Represents the direction of left.
Right unit vector. Represents the direction of right.
Up unit vector. Y is down in 2D, so this vector points -Y.
Down unit vector. Y is down in 2D, so this vector points +Y.

operator.name: operator !=
operator.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if the vectors are not equal.

operator.name: operator %
operator.description: Gets the remainder of each component of the [Vector2i] with the components of the given [Vector2i]. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [method @GlobalScope.posmod] instead if you want to handle negative numbers. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, -20) % Vector2i(7, 8)) # Prints (3, -4) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator %
operator.description: Gets the remainder of each component of the [Vector2i] with the given [int]. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [method @GlobalScope.posmod] instead if you want to handle negative numbers. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, -20) % 7) # Prints (3, -6) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) * Vector2i(3, 4)) # Prints (30, 80) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [float]. Returns a [Vector2]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 15) * 0.9) # Prints (9.0, 13.5) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [int].

operator.name: operator +
operator.description: Adds each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) + Vector2i(3, 4)) # Prints (13, 24) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator -
operator.description: Subtracts each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) - Vector2i(3, 4)) # Prints (7, 16) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector2i] by the components of the given [Vector2i]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(10, 20) / Vector2i(2, 5)) # Prints (5, 4) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [float]. Returns a [Vector2]. [codeblock] print(Vector2i(1, 2) / 2.5) # Prints (0.4, 0.8) [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector2i] by the given [int].

operator.name: operator <
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator <=
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than or equal to the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator ==
operator.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if the vectors are equal.

operator.name: operator >
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator >=
operator.description: Compares two [Vector2i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than or equal to the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator []
operator.description: Access vector components using their [param index]. [code]v[0][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.x[/code], and [code]v[1][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.y[/code].

operator.name: operator unary+
operator.description: Returns the same value as if the [code]+[/code] was not there. Unary [code]+[/code] does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

operator.name: operator unary-
operator.description: Returns the negative value of the [Vector2i]. This is the same as writing [code]Vector2i(-v.x, -v.y)[/code]. This operation flips the direction of the vector while keeping the same magnitude.
